11:12 am
BE11:13am

C1Q19 Earnings Recap: Apple’s C1Q was a solid bounce back vs. a difficult
December, with better-than-expected results on both revenue ($58.0bn vs.
CSe/Street $57.9bn/$57.5bn) and EPS ($2.46 vs. CSe/Street $2.40/$2.36).
Commentary around improving iPhone trends through the quarter was
encouraging, with management noting the most challenging months
(Nov/Dec) are in the rear-view mirror and the pace of decline was
significantly smaller in the last few weeks of March. The recently enacted FXrelated
price cuts in EMs are likely having a positive impact, albeit with a
corresponding drag on Product gross margins (-2.7pts y/y); we expect a
more muted pricing strategy on the fall 2019 iPhone launch, particularly
internationally. Greater China (-22% y/y) remains a key swing factor ahead,
as near-term cyclical factors (i.e., macro and trade tensions) appear to be
easing, but we’re concerned underlying structural headwinds remain given
market saturation and aggressive local competition. Finally on Services,
revenue ($11.5bn, +16% y/y) reached an all-time high as Apple continues to
shift toward monetizing its massive 900mn/1.4bn iPhone/total device
installed base; App Store in particular posted a record quarter despite the
ongoing headwind from a regulatory-related slowdown in China gaming.

BE11:13am

Our View: While “less bad” is a significant improvement from the rough start
to the year, we remain Neutral as we see a long road to recovery for iPhone
with a ~1yr jump in the net replacement cycle in CY19 (per CSe) and further
extension ahead of 5G in 2H20. Further, while we recognize the potential in
the shift to Services we don’t think it’s enough to move estimates
meaningfully higher over the near-to-medium term, leaving upside for the
stock more dependent on the multiple re-rating higher. Against a backdrop of
sizeable iPhone sales declines (CSe -10% in CY19), we think the investor
perception of Apple as a hardware-centric company will be tough to shake.
With the stock trading near a peak multiple (~15x our CY20 EPS), we remain
on the sidelines awaiting a better entry point and/or line-of sight to significant
Services-led upside.

BE11:13am

And Goldman.

11:13 am
BE11:14am

While iPhone numbers were weaker than we had expected we were pleasantly surprised by positive trends in iPad, Wearable and Mac in both reported revenues and guidance. In guidance, we believe that new iPad Mini/Air models, Airpods and non-CPU supply constrained Macs add up to slightly better revenue even as iPhone results remain lackluster. Though in line with our above consensus expectations we point out that guided Opex implies operating margins of ~21% that have not been seen since 2008 when the iPhone was just getting started. We believe fundamentals get more challenging as the year progresses and that the stock remains toward the top of its valuation range vs. the S&P 500. We reiterate our Neutral rating.

BE11:14am

FQ3 revenue guidance beat driven by everything but
niPhone. Apple guided for FQ3 revenue of $52.5bn - $54.5bn, beating our estimate by 2% and consensus by 3%. Based on management’s commentary on non-iPhone seasonality heading into the June quarter and the actual reported segment level revenues, we believe the 2% beat vs. our estimate is primarily due to iPads, Macs, Watches and other non-iPhone items while the iPhone performance remains largely inline with our previous estimate. We believe that new iPad Mini/Air updates, Macs and Airpods should be particularly strong in FQ3 to June. Apple also said the guidance includes a negative FX impact of 300bps to revenue.

JP11:14am

Capex declined year-on-year -- $7.0 to $5.7bn -- and R&D was up marginally. So it's not like they're using the cash to set themselves up in other business lines.

11:14 am
JP11:14am

Which, is a point made by Neil Campling of Mirabaud:

JP11:15am

Fact. 2Q revenue of $58.02B was ahead of FS $57.54B with EPS of $2.46 ahead of FS $2.36. iPhone revenue of $31.05B was ahead of consensus $30.93B with iPad $4.87B above consensus $4.23B Mac $5.51B below consensus $5.90B and Services of $11.45B above consensus $11.37B. 3Q revenue guidance of $52.5-54.5M ahead of FS $52.10B with gross margin of 37-38% below FS 37.9%. Board has announced an additional $75B for share repurchases and increased its quarterly dividend +5% to $0.77.

Thought: Don’t look over there… look over there. 65% of the business might rely on one key driver (aka iPhones) which is in severe decline (iPhone sales fell 17% YoY in the quarter) so the company has been trying to divert attention to services as the key high growth driver of the future. But these other services of app sales, streaming sales etc. only grew 16% YoY. It isn’t at the hyper growth level it needs to be.

So, in shades of IBM (not a good sign to be clear) Apple play their financial Ace card – increase the size of their buyback by $75B – the magnitude of which is more than the market cap of many companies. This doesn’t smack of innovation, or of investing to find the crest of the next technology wave, or to disrupt current ecosystems. It smacks of establishment, of conformity, of a lack of innovation and inspiration.

Remember the iconic Apple “think different” campaign ? “Here’s to the crazy ones, the misfits, the rebels, the troublemakers, the round pegs in the square holes… the ones who see things differently — they’re not fond of rules… You can quote them, disagree with them, glorify or vilify them, but the only thing you can’t do is ignore them because they change things… they push the human race forward, and while some may see them as the crazy ones, we see genius, because the ones who are crazy enough to think that they can change the world, are the ones who do.” Steve Jobs, 1997. There isn’t anything different about this current 2019 version of Apple – we wish there was.

BE11:18am

Here is 5 Reasons Why Apple As a Trillion
Market Cap Can Go Higher
It is no surprise that we get a lot of pushback on our Buy rating on Apple given 1) its
large market cap, 2) iPhone sales have entered negative growth 3) Android has
more market share and less expensive average selling points and 4) investors feel
innovation at Apple has been lacking. Accordingly we lay out 5 reasons we believe
Apple can trade higher
Applewood part 1: increased services will gradually be an increasing part of Apple
user lives and Apple highlighted its users increased literally in all products and
geographies.
Applewood part 2: expansion of footprint in developing countries. Our research work
shows Apple is physically expanding its manufacturing footprint into India where the
company has less than 2% market share and no Apple owned/operated stores.
Once the company manufactures in India we believe the company will be granted
the ability by the government to open stores in India which we expect in late 2019 or
2020. The following is a recap from our May 11 2018 note: AAPL: Updating Our
Thesis on Applewood; Why We still Like Apple.
Apple Pay: Not just the attractive rebates ranging from 3% to 1% but also the
convenience of soon to be adopted via more mass transit systems which cause
consumers to become much more familiar with Apple Pay for normal transactions
and greatly helps with adoption. Payments across Apple users are at the infancy
stage which will help adoption and usage.
Tremendous R&D which results in innovation of new products and services. Sure
12 years ago the iPhone was iconic and literally changed the behavior and lives of
many. To those who talk down Apple’s recent innovation we point to the Apple
watch and wireless air pods which are best selling products and changing behavior
and lives of many. Looking ahead perhaps Apple becomes a portal for ride sharing,
home security, education portal, disintermediation for currency via Apple pay and
funds transfer, healthcare service solution, cloud storage of information for personal
and business data, Apple TV and music portals, and disintermediation of the
gaming industry, etc. If an Apple user thinks about how much they pay Apple today
versus a decade ago the average answer is more and we see this continuing. In
2014 we wrote an Apple Crystal Ball report which can be found at this link and is
still a relevant report. AAPL: Apple Pay & Passbook: Looking into the Crystal
Ball .....
Valuation and capital returns. Apple trades at 10-20% discount to the market and
has a dividend yield of 2% and a $75 billion authorized stock buy back all of which
create valuation support. As services grow which have gross margins in the 60%
range compared to hardware in the 30% range one can argue that Apple’s cash
flow and valuation multiple could expand in the future.

JP11:19am

Here's Richard Windsor of Radio Free Mobile for good measure:

JP11:19am

Apple reported what was considered to be good results as the iPhone business showed greater stabilisation than the more pessimistic end of the market had feared.
FQ2 19 revenues EPS was $58.0bn $2.46 compared to consensus at $57.5bn $2.38.
Guidance was also ahead of expectations with FQ3 19 revenues gross margins expected at $52.5bn – $54.5bn 37% – 38% compared with consensus at $52.1bn 37.6%.
Emerging markets and especially China continue to be a challenge as Apple’s latest crop of products has triggered more price sensitive users to hold onto their devices for longer.
However, in developed markets, the impact has been less which combined with solid growth in services (albeit relatively small), has helped offset the 17% decline in iPhone revenues YoY.
The net result is a fairly stable outlook where very low growth and steady margins will keep cash generation at very healthy levels.
Apple’s growth outlook is way below that of its peers but this is also reflected in its valuation and so I remain fairly indifferent to the shares although some profit taking would not be out of order.

BE11:23am

Supply chain implications: non-iPhone segments leading to better
seasonal decline for Jun-Q; y-y iPhone rev decline should shrink in Jun-Q
 We think Apple’s Jun-Q revenue guidance shows a slower seasonal q-q
decline, led by growth in non-iPhone segments. In our view, guidance also
implies an improvement in the y-y iPhone revenue decline, from -17% y-y
in Mar-Q, to -10~15% y-y in Jun-Q (vs consensus expecting -15% y-y).
 Buy iPhone plays at bottom. From a higher-level iPhone-cycle point of
view, we believe the worst is over (Jun-Q should mark the bottom) for
Apple’s iPhone supply chain. The recent settlement between Apple
and QCOM, in our view, should lead to a stronger 5G iPhone portfolio
for 2H20F, together with a major design architecture upgrade for
iPhone in 2HCY20F (usually architecture upgrades happens every three
years; the last was iPhone X in 2HCY17). In addition, we expect Apple to
roll out an iPhone SE2 in 1HCY20F, which may imply an easier y-y
comparison in 1HCY20F (vs. no new model in 1HCY19). Hence, in light of
cycle bottoming, and with a clearer roadmap to CY20 (SE2 and 5G
phones), we recently upgraded several iPhone suppliers, including AAC (2018 HK, Buy), Goertek (002241 CH, Buy), and Flexium (6269
TT, Buy). We also reiterate our Buy calls on ZDT (4958 TT), Largan
(3008 TT), Catcher (2474 TT).
 We remain positive on AirPod plays. We think in Apple’s strong
wearables and accessories sales, AirPod should be the major contributor
of the strength. We continue to like Luxshare (002475 CH, Buy), which is
the major source of AirPod assembly and a key component supplier for
Apple Watch, as it is evolving to increase value-add for the products, even
including SiP (see our report: A step forward). AirPod and TWS (true
wireless stereo) earbud growth was also a reason we recently upgraded
Goertek (a second source of AirPod assembly) to Buy.
 iPad growth likely peaking for supply chain: iPad (revenue +22% y-y in
Mar-Q and +17% y-y in Dec-Q) was a bright spot in Apple’s results over
the past two quarters, driven by good sales of the new iPad Pros,
according to Apple. iPad component suppliers’ sales (eg, Radiant, GIS,
TPK) grew 20-30% y-y in Dec-Q and 30%+ y-y in Mar-Q due to the
frequent new product refreshes (11”, 12.5”, 10.5”, 7.9”) in the past two
quarters. We expect sales of iPad suppliers to decline q-q in 2QCY19F
(but may still be up y-y), and 2HCY19F y-y sales growth to slow, given the
high base in 2HCY18. We are more cautious about the iPad supply chain,
given the already high sales/earnings bases.

11:28 am
JP11:28am

Trading – timing is everything. H1 revenues were down -8% on an organic CER basis (-5.3% net) and adj PBT was -27% at CER; this was due to two main factors, which were not specific to AVON and which were outlined in the Q1 update: first, the US government partial shutdown impacted orders being processed in Law Enforcement, and second, the weakness in the milk price impacted confidence and therefore spending amongst dairy farmers globally. Added to that, the timing of the significant new contract wins and orders for both M53A1 and M69 powered air respirators means initial revenues from those will come in H2, with none falling into H1. The outlook remains confident, with the closing order book up 40%, giving comfort on the FY number – milk price/feed price dynamics have improved trading in Dairy, and in Military the recent contract wins mean the medium-term outlook is materially enhanced, with Military forecasts now underpinned for three years at the very least. We also reiterate the point that the new products come in at a higher margin, with a higher proportion of aftermarket revenues so the mix is improving.

Tom Dalgleish DRAM prices down 30% https://www.fool.com/investing/2019/03/06/dram-prices-are-falling-off-a-cliff.aspx
Geektrader hi
JP11:29am

Forecasts – FY20 upgrade. Our FY19 forecasts remain unchanged despite the setback in H1, and we are upgrading our FY20E EPS by a conservative 2%, to 81.9p, due to the M69 and M53A1 contracts being slightly larger than we were anticipating – we would argue upside risk remains, especially from RoW customers and from potential MCM100 orders. Cash generation has been strong, as ever, and net cash at the end of the half was at £46.8m (PHe FY unch at £56.2m). TP to 1,600p. Given the upgrade and the increased underpin to our medium-term revenue outlook, the positive momentum from new products hitting the market, and the strength of the balance sheet giving estimated firepower of £130m for acquisitions, we are increasing our TP to 1,600p from 1,500p, which equates to a PER of 19.5x our new Sep20 forecast. AVON remains a top pick in the sector and we reiterate our Buy recommendation. The shares are currently trading on 18x and yield 1.4%.

JP11:31am

Years of under-investment is now taking its toll on revenues and profit margin. In constant currency terms, five of the six business segments suffered a decline in sales of -1% to -38% YoY in H1/19, and we do not see this reversing. This means that any hope of growth in the medium term now rests on Military, which grew 7.2% in H1/19. However, the recent US DoD IDIQ (Indefinite Delivery Indefinite Quantity) wins does not provide the visibility of the 10-year M50 contract. Total capex in H1/19 at £4.1m was purely maintenance capex. We continue to believe that revenues and profits will decline over the 2019-21 period unless the management invests in growth. There is no change to our forecasts, Target Price or recommendation.

In other words, H2/FY19 will need to account for 58% and 70% of revenues and operating profits, respectively, in FY19.The company remains confident on delivery of its current year expectations thanks to the US DoD contract awards for the M53A1 and M69 mask systems, worth $340m over 5 years. However, we note that this is the maximum amount, there is a risk that actual revenues will be lower. It is also important to highlight that M53A1 is a framework contract where Avon has less visibility over the likely order profile.

BE11:49am

Tate & Lyle’s full-year numbers are due on 23 May. We believe consensus
is expecting too much, especially in the light of ADM’s recent earnings
release which flagged higher logistical costs around Decatur, Illinois
(where Tate’s largest facility is located). We are 3% below consensus
EBIT for the full-year, implying that we are 6% below consensus for H2.

BE11:49am

KECH: 6% below consensus EBIT for H2, EPS guidance at risk
While we believe consensus estimates for Food & Beverage solutions and
Sucralose are largely fair, we strongly question sell-side’s expectations for
profitability in Sweeteners & Starches. Apart from weaker profits in the
reported April-December 2018 period, we believe Q4 will likely be
impacted by higher logistical costs at two of Tate’s largest plants, in
Decatur, Illinois and Lafayette, Indiana. This puts the full-year guidance of
c. 4% adj. EPS growth at risk.
Reduce, TP of 620p
At over 15.5x 2020/21E P/E, Tate & Lyle is, in our view, not attractively
valued. We foresee declining operating profitability in 2019/20E, as: 1) we
feel processing profitability has peaked; and 2) we question the
sustainability of the strong performance in Sucralose. We have a Reduce
rating and a 620p TP, which we reach by using a DCF (8.2% WACC; 1.5%
long-term growth) and a comparison to Ingredion.

Key numbers:

· Retail 4Q LFL: -0.9%, vs Barclays -1.3% (see table for details).

· Retail FY underlying EBIT: £692mn (margin = 2.43%), vs Barclays £682mn (margin =2.39%).

· FY underlying PBT: £635mn, vs Barclays £627mn (company-collected consensus £626mn).

· This implies a 2H yoy PBT decrease of -1.5%, after +20.3% in 1H.

· Net debt (including perpetual securities): £1,636mn vs Barclays £1,612mn.

· Net debt fell by £222mn, versus guidance of c£100mn.

· Net pension surplus: £743mn, an improvement of £575mn vs £168mn at 1H.

· DPS: 11.0p, vs Barclays 10.9p, consensus of 10.5p.

· Exceptional costs related to proposed ASDA merger amounted to £46m (vs £17m in 1H).

· Sainsbury expects IFRS 16 would have negatively impacted 18/19 PBT by c£30mn (c4.5-5.0%).

Swedes Caster your eye over the EBIT for H2.
BE11:59am

First impressions:

· We break down total sales growth by category in the table below. We can see that total Grocery sales growth decelerated by 1.0ppt between 3Q and 4Q.

· General merchandise showed much better sales trends than in the prior quarter.

· New GUIDANCE: Sainsbury guides to net debt reduction of “at least” £600m over three years. It is planning work on greater than 400 stores this year (but capex guidance of £550m is unchanged). Bank capital injections will be £80m this year (vs previous guidance of £100m). Sainsbury makes no comment on PBT consensus of £652m for 19/20 (but is aware it would need to say something if this was plainly unachievable).

· Company also acknowledges need to focus more on store standards and prices on commodity items.

· Sainsbury announces a CMD for 25 September.

· CONCLUSION: Against quite low expectations and very negative sentiment, the company seems to be addressing some of investors’ key concerns. Cash generation was stronger than expected in 18/19 and is clearly a major focus going forwards.

And here's UBS for good measure:

JP12:01pm

Margin stabilized but growth potential remains limited. We stay Neutral.
Sainsbury's FY18/19 results were largely in-line with expectations, with management comments around strategy perhaps more evolutionary and less revelatory, than expected. We're making no changes to our model at this time [management seems comfortable with cons']. Whilst LfL sales have been lacklustre, we think profitability in the core retail business can be sustained mid-term. Ex. synergy margin have bottomed-out after several years of decline and the cost plan should more than offset inflation. The stock trades on 11.1x P/E [FY20e], with a c.5.0% dividend yield. This is an optically undemanding valuation. Nevertheless, given limited growth potential, prospects for multiple expansion aren't obvious at this moment. Neutral.

BE12:02pm

Conclusion: Today's results confirm a clear deterioration in grocery sales, while at
this stage the drivers helping margin resilience are unclear. A new target for a 3yr
£600m net debt reduction (CMD on 25 Sep) suggests a shift in the equity story to
FC merits. But at this juncture we stay on Hold on a 2020 cal PE/FCY of 10.4x/8.3%,
reflecting concerns that SBRY may need more drastic commercial action to address
current -ve trading momentum.
Details: SBRY reported FY PBT of £635m (JEFe/cons £618m/£626m), with H2 retail
margin +11bps after +36bps in H1. A Q4 LFL of -0.9% was less pressured than
feared (JEFe -1.5% inc cal), but confirmed soft Grocery sales (total -0.6%) more than
offsetting improved GM (+1.5%) while Clothing was mixed (-1.6%). Final DPS of 7.9p
takes the total to 11p. The outlook statement notes an uncertain and competitive
retail and consumer environment. Whether this is compatible with 19/20 PBT cons
of £652m (JEFe £646m) is uncertain at this stage.

JP12:03pm

At a headline level Sainsbury's reported FY2019 PTP of £635m (SC forecast £646m), EPS of 22.0p (SC forecast 20.1p), yoy growth of 7.8%. The Group has declared a final DPS of 7.9p, so making for a full-year pay-out of 11.0p, covered 2.0x by headline EPS.

Of the Group's trading performance, Sainsbury's Retail sales increased by 0.4% in the year with Grocery up 0.6%, Clothing sales down 0.8% and General Merchandise (which includes Argos) flat yoy at £6.56bn. Sainsbury's Supermarkets have demonstrably underperformed the UK grocery market for much of FY2019 with the Q4 Grocery LFL declining -0.6% (total Group LFL down 1.6%) and current secondary market share data from the likes of Nielsen (30th April 2019) suggests an ongoing lag, which is concerning to us as to its implications for operational gearing and working capital.

Underlying Retail operating profits (excluding aforementioned exceptional items) were £692m, +10.7% yoy, reflecting full delivery of a further £68m of Argos EBIT synergies in the year. Sainsbury Bank confirmed a poor financial out-turn, reporting trading profits of just £32m, in line with guidance but down 55% yoy. So, a challenging year for Sainsbury's from a revenue perspective underpinned by delivery of the final phase of targeted Argos synergies, and a year that ultimately ended with bitterness and frustration with last week's statement on the CMA's prohibition of its Asda marriage.

12:04 pm
JP12:04pm

Key guidance outlined in the statement is:

Accelerating investment in store estate and technology while reducing net debt and maintaining dividend policy
Investment in the core, to “improve” 400 supermarkets this year – FY2020 capex guided at £550m
New guidance to reduce net debt by at least £600m over the next three years
A Capital Markets Day is planned for 25th September to “update further on progress”
All in all, we remain concerned about Sainsbury's as a business, where it has reached, especially following the optimism surrounding the potential of the Group when it completed the acquisition of Argos in September 2016. We still applaud Mike Coupe for that deal, believing it to be well thought - through. However, whilst progress with Argos has been satisfactory to our minds, the performance and relative competitiveness of the Group's Supermarkets and Bank worries us.

We will reflect and issue updated forecasts

We see no cost-free or quick turnaround, again, for Sainsbury's Supermarkets whilst the Bank must seek to build from its re-based level. We will reflect upon today's analyst meeting before finessing our financial forecasts for the Group. However, given the context set out above, we believe that the outlook is challenged and we worry about the trajectory of EPS and, correspondingly, DPS paying capabilities. We place our FY2020 CPTP forecast of £685m under review, though fully expect to be downgrading.

12:07 pm
BE12:07pm

The outlook for Online Takeaway platforms remains bright - but
investors can't afford to play just a single theme, as share price
performances are likely to diverge further from here. We have highlighted
several times that running a hybrid model is key - successful companies will
be determined by: 1) level of tech execution and consumer experience
delivered and 2) having the right (not the most) restaurants available on their
platform. Those unable to execute on these metrics could be penalized with
further market share losses. Our top pick in the space is Delivery Hero, which
we move to OW from N and add to the AFL. We also continue to like
Takeaway.com (OW) but turn bearish again on JUST EAT (moving to UW
from OW), as we see ongoing weakness in the UK and market share losses.

Patience @Excel - have never voted Tory in my life - nor my parents, nor my children. We're just not rich enough.
BE12:08pm

Just Eat's structural challenges become increasingly visible. With
more than 100% of EBITDA, the UK remains the key share price driver - and the UK
business is slowing quickly with +7% order growth in Q1 (after +13% in
Q418). High exposure to less attractive restaurants, cannibalization from
delivery restaurants (finally) signed up on the JE platform and poor tech
execution vs. peers appears to have taken its toll. We expect order growth
for the UK to remain subdued going forward and materially reduce our UK
valuation from £2.3bn to £1.7bn which causes our SOTP-based Dec 2019
target price to fall from 822p to 682p. Our 2020E/2021E EBITDA (group)
expectations are -11%/-17% below BBG consensus. M&A is a risk now but
we see limited appetite for large scale disposals among JE shareholders.

Purplebricks Group PLC (PURP:LSE): Last: 133.80, down 0.2 (-0.15%), High: 137.40, Low: 130.60, Volume: 51.14k
12:08 pm
BE12:08pm

Assume coverage with a Sell rating and a 100p SOTP-based price target
Purplebricks' share price has fallen -60% in the LTM, but we see further downside
given: 1) UK momentum has worsened, market share gains have slowed and risks are
skewed to the downside; 2) tough competitive dynamics in the US means we expect
losses and FCF burn to worsen and break-even could take five years; and 3) further
funding may be needed given current cash resources and slow UK growth may not be
enough to fund the US. We think a capital raise is most likely given the company's track
record; bank borrowing could be expensive and would add further pressure to cash
flow generation. We factor in a £100m capital raise in FY20E.
Upfront fee model still viable but UBS Evidence Lab shows worsening traction
UBS Evidence Lab data shows UK momentum has worsened and Purplebricks' market
share gains have slowed from +150bps yoy in early 2018 to +50bps yoy ytd. We see
risks from prolonged Brexit uncertainty; a potential change to the pricing model and
recent management changes. However, we think there is still some room to grow. We
expect Purplebricks to grow share from +5.7% currently to 8% long term, but below
guidance of 10%, driven by: 1) an attractive consumer offer with savings of c£1500; 2)
favourable competitive dynamics in the online market where scale is key to success; and
3) improving penetration in London and premium properties where Purplebricks lags.

BE12:09pm

US losses likely to increase, FCF burn to worsen… more funding may be needed
Investment in the US has tripled that of the UK and we expect losses in the US to
worsen driven by: 1) tough competition with Redfin, a US hybrid estate agent who
could challenge Purplebricks with cheaper fees in some regions; 2) challenging agent
economics with upward pressure on agents' compensation to improve retention; and 3)
higher advertising spend to drive brand awareness. We expect group FCF burn to
worsen from -£18m in FY18 to -£53m in FY19E and FY20E and to break even in FY23E.
In our view, current cash resources and slow UK growth may not be enough to fund US
losses. We believe more funding may be needed with a capital raise likely in FY2020E.

BE12:09pm

Valuation: 100p SOTP-DCF based PT, 300p upside case vs 55p downside
We value the UK at an EV of £260m (62p per share) given long-term market share of
8% and EBITDA margins of 10%. We value the US at an EV of £30m (7p) assuming
break-even in FY25E. We also factor in a £100m capital raise. Upside risks include
better execution in the US with losses improving post FY19 and Purplebricks having
strategic value in the UK as a #1 dominant hybrid estate agent
